ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Right Hemisphere Auditory Cortex Lesion (RMCA Stroke)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of RMCA stroke, left ear deficits on central tests (contralateral to lesion), and absent MLR over the right hemisphere.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Basic assessment of peripheral hearing sensitivity.
Central auditory test to assess interhemispheric transfer and cortical function.
Central auditory test sensitive to cortical lesions.
Low-redundancy speech test to assess temporal processing.
Assessment of temporal patterning and sequencing.
Assessment of frequency discrimination and patterning.
Cortical evoked potentials to assess auditory cortex function.
Event-related potential to assess cognitive auditory processing.
Review of radiologic findings to confirm lesion site.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Peripheral hearing was essentially normal with excellent speech recognition. Central testing revealed significant deficits in the left ear (contralateral to the right hemisphere lesion) on dichotic and low-redundancy speech tasks. Electrophysiology showed an absent Middle Latency Response (MLR) over the right hemisphere (T4), consistent with the lesion. Interestingly, pattern perception tests were normal, likely preserved due to the patient's musical background.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Left ear thresholds 0-10 dB HL; Right ear 10-20 dB HL sloping to 30-35 dB HL at 4-8 kHz.

tests.name: Dichotic Rhyme test
tests.result_summary: Significant deficit in the left ear (~30%).

tests.name: Middle latency response (MLR)
tests.result_summary: Absent/poor responses at T4 (right/lesion side); normal responses at T3.

tests.name: Late potentials (N1/P2)
tests.result_summary: Smaller amplitudes for right hemisphere (C4) recordings and left ear stimulation; extended latencies.

tests.name: CT scan review
tests.result_summary: Large area of encephalomalacia in right frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes consistent with RMCA stroke.

proposed_items: Strategies for improving listening in noise
counseling_actions: Explain that the subjective 'hearing loss' in the left ear is due to the right hemisphere brain lesion affecting processing from the contralateral ear, not a peripheral ear problem.
Discuss amusia (difficulty with music) as a direct result of the right hemisphere injury, which specializes in melody and spectral processing.
Highlight the preserved ability to process duration and frequency patterns as a strength, likely related to prior musical expertise.
Validate the patient's difficulty in noise as a central processing issue.

escalation.rationale_short: Patient is a stable research case with established stroke sequelae.

expected_outcome: Subjective left ear hearing difficulty attributed to central lesion affecting contralateral perception.
Amusia and inability to sing consistent with right hemisphere lesion.
Preserved pattern perception attributed to prior musical expertise/plasticity.
Normal P300 attributed to preserved cognitive sharpness despite large lesion.
